author: By Paul Mozur and Cade Metz
title: Security Flaws Seen in China’s Mandatory Olympics App for Athletes
description: Researchers said the app, which will store sensitive health data on participants at the Winter Games, has serious encryption vulnerabilities.
content: The mandatory smartphone app that athletes will use to report health and travel data when they are in China for the Olympics next month has serious encryption flaws, according to a new report, raising security questions about the systems that Beijing plans to use to track Covid-19 outbreaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Sudan’s Security Forces Kill Protesters as U.S. Diplomats’ Visit Nears
description: Seven people died after being shot at demonstrations in the northeast African country, a doctors’ group said, bringing the civilian death toll since the military seized back power to 71.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Sudanese security forces killed seven people and injured at least 100 others on Monday, a doctors’ group said, the latest bloody protest to shake the country ahead of a visit by senior American diplomats seeking to support the revival of Sudan’s faltering transition to democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: N.B.A.’s Warriors Disavow Part-Owner’s Uyghur Comments
description: The Golden State Warriors distanced themselves from a minority stakeholder, Chamath Palihapitiya, who said “nobody cares” about the Uyghurs, the ethnic group that has faced a deadly crackdown in China.
content: The N.B.A.’s Golden State Warriors on Monday distanced themselves from a partial stakeholder in the team after he said “nobody cares about what’s happening to the Uyghurs,” the predominantly Muslim minority that has faced widespread repression in China’s western Xinjiang region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Stocks drop as Treasury bond yields push higher.
description: Stocks tumbled on Tuesday, as Treasury yields kept climbing above prepandemic levels, and disappointing results from another major Wall Street bank dragged the financial sector lower.
content: Stocks tumbled on Tuesday, as Treasury yields kept climbing above prepandemic levels, and disappointing results from another major Wall Street bank dragged the financial sector lower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei, Frances Robles and Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Judge Approves Deal to Resolve Puerto Rico Bankruptcy
description: The plan restructures $33 billion in debt nearly five years after Puerto Rico became the first U.S. state or territory to essentially declare bankruptcy.
content: MIAMI — Puerto Rico received approval from a federal judge on Tuesday to leave bankruptcy under the largest public-sector debt restructuring deal in the history of the United States, nearly five years after the financially strapped territory declared it could not repay its creditors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and David McCabe
title: AT&T and Verizon Delay 5G Service Near Some Airports
description: Whether the change would end the long conflict between the telecom and aviation industries wasn’t clear.
content: Verizon and AT&T said on Tuesday that they would delay the expansion of new 5G cellular service near some airports, a pause that President Biden said would avert potentially devastating disruptions that airlines had been warning about for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deirdre Mask
title: They Wanted to Write the History of Modern China. But How?
description: In the historian Jing Tsu’s “Kingdom of Characters,” the evolution of Chinese writing tells the story of the country’s past, present — and future.
content: KINGDOM OF CHARACTERSThe Language Revolution That Made China ModernBy Jing Tsu
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: A Race to Dominate the Metaverse
description: Microsoft said it planned to buy the video game company Activision Blizzard for nearly $70 billion.
content: Microsoft agreed to buy Activision Blizzard, the video game maker behind hits like Call of Duty and Candy Crush, for $68.7 billion in cash. The deal will position Microsoft for the next generation of the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: America’s Next Great Restaurants Are in the Suburbs. But Can They Thrive There?
description: With a shift in demographics and tastes, chefs are finding an unexpected home for their ambitious cuisine.
content: ST. CHARLES, Mo. — The flavors at the Peruvian restaurant Jalea are electric. The location? A bit more unassuming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Eric Adams Ran on Making New York Safer. A Subway Killing Poses a Test.
description: The mayor, who made improving public safety a theme of his campaign, is dealing with the fallout from a high-profile death in Times Square.
content: Not long after winning New York City’s Democratic primary, Eric Adams had a quick answer to the question of how his potential mayoralty should be judged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italy Ponders a New Role for Draghi. Let the Politicking Begin.
description: Prime Minister Mario Draghi is in the running to be the next president, a powerful but often-ceremonial role that could take his hand off day-to-day affairs.
content: ROME — Just a few months ago at an international summit in Rome, President Biden privately told Prime Minister Mario Draghi of Italy that when it came to showing that democracies can function well, “You are doing it.” For good measure, he added, according to a person in the room, the Italian had a “hell of a political operation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Bassin
title: Is Civil War Coming to America?
description: Two books, “How Civil Wars Start,” by Barbara F. Walter, and “The Next Civil War,” by Stephen Marche, examine if the United States is facing upheaval.
content: HOW CIVIL WARS STARTAnd How to Stop ThemBy Barbara F. Walter
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: A.V. Club staff members lose their jobs after refusing a move to Los Angeles.
description: The employees’ union was critical of G/O Media’s plan to close the Chicago office and relocate workers without a cost-of-living adjustment.
content: The staff of The A.V. Club, the Chicago-based pop culture website published by G/O Media, was given a choice: accept a relocation to Los Angeles or leave the publication with a severance package. On Tuesday, seven people on the staff said they had decided to stay put — and give up their jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Why Can’t We Turn Away From the N.F.L.?
description: The exploding viewership for N.F.L. games and the league’s ever-expanding season resist all scandal and reason. Our columnist asks why.
content: The N.F.L. does not care about your concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Grammy Awards Move to April in Las Vegas
description: The 64th annual show, originally scheduled for Jan. 31 in Los Angeles, was postponed amid a spike in Covid-19 cases. It will now take place on April 3, and be broadcast live by CBS.
content: The 64th annual Grammy Awards will take place on April 3 at the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas, the show’s organizers announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: As Johnson Reels From Scandals, Is Someone Plotting to Take His Place?
description: A key question is: Will the results of an inquiry over parties in Downing Street during lockdown push a fellow conservative to move against Prime Minister Boris Johnson?
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson may have crossed a political Rubicon in recent days over charges that he lied about Downing Street parties during the pandemic. But whether he is forced out of power could depend on whether one of his fellow Conservatives is ready to play the role of Brutus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Coffee, Italian Style, in East Harlem
description: Dell’Aria Coffee Roasters celebrates the bean, with a training lab for would-be baristas, along with a coffee shop for aficionados.
content: An Italian-style coffee roaster has come to East Harlem. Michele Maturo, a native of Milan and a coffee aficionado, is consulting with Jake Leonti, a professional roaster, to process green beans from various countries into blends, both Italian and American style, to sell retail and wholesale. Beyond the handsome dark navy brick facade punctuated with a glass garage door is a huge blue roaster resembling a 19th-century locomotive. Coffee is brewed and served using assorted systems at the food counter that also sells excellent housemade breakfast pastries, ciambelli doughnuts, cakes, panini, salumi and gelati. There is seating for about 25 at marble tables. A training lab for baristas, and classes for SCA (Specialty Coffee Association) and MuMac Academy of Milan certifications are coming. Vintage coffee machines will also be on display. Mr. Maturo said he selected the location as a nod to the Italian history of the neighborhood; it seems to be catching on as a gathering place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Strasser
title: What It’s Like to Live Through a Rupture in History
description: “Free,” by Lea Ypi, is a memoir about growing up in Albania amid the fall of communism.
content: FREEA Child and a Country at the End of HistoryBy Lea Ypi
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Hong Kong will cull thousands of hamsters after Covid cases in a pet shop.
description: Officials said it was not clear that the virus had been transmitted to humans from the animals. But they called on residents to surrender recently imported hamsters.
content: Hong Kong will cull more than 2,000 hamsters and ban the import of small animals after a pet shop worker, a customer and at least 11 hamsters tested positive for the Delta variant of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Coleman
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $1.37 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Examining the Spike in Murders
description: The effects are felt unequally across the U.S.
content: In 2020, murders in the United States spiked more than 27 percent — the largest percentage increase in at least six decades. Last year, murders went up again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Herring
title: How Pat Riley Quit On the Knicks
description: In a book excerpt, a writer details the Knicks’ infighting and the tense contract negotiations that led Coach Pat Riley to leave for the Miami Heat in 1995.
content: The following are excerpts from “Blood in the Garden: The Flagrant History of the 1990s New York Knicks” by Chris Herring. They have been edited and condensed. The book was released Tuesday. Herring is a senior writer at Sports Illustrated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Kazakhstan’s Former Leader Speaks Out on Unrest That Gripped the Country
description: Nursultan Nazarbayev, who had been absent during the recent unrest that gripped the country, said he supported the country’s leader and the economic reforms he has proposed.
content: NUR-SULTAN, Kazakhstan — Kazakhstan’s long-serving former president, who was conspicuously absent during the unrest that rocked the country this month, posted a video on Tuesday with his first public comments since the violence erupted, saying he supported the country’s leader and the economic reforms he has proposed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced
title: It’s Not ‘Woke’ for Businesses to Think Beyond Profit, BlackRock Chief Says
description: Larry Fink’s latest annual letter to corporate America clarifies, and defends, his approach to social and environmental issues at the world’s largest money manager.
content: Laurence D. Fink, the founder and chief executive of the investment giant BlackRock, has become one of the most influential voices in business over the past decade in pushing corporate leaders to think beyond profits, to their social purpose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Appears Skeptical of Boston’s Refusal to Fly Christian Flag
description: The court seemed poised to rule that the city, which has approved many other requests to raise flags at its City Hall, violated a Christian group’s free speech rights.
content: WASHINGTON — The City of Boston, which refused to let a private group raise a Christian flag in front of its City Hall, seemed to be headed for a loss after a Supreme Court argument on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter C. Baker
title: How a Boy in Rural Iceland Became a Tool for Global Fascism
description: “Red Milk,” a novel by Sjón, examines a young man’s path to neo-Nazism.
content: RED MILKBy SjónTranslated by Victoria Cribb
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua M. Sharfstein
title: The C.D.C. and F.D.A. Can Work Better Together
description: Among the agencies’ major challenges during the pandemic has been collaboration.
content: At this difficult moment of the pandemic, a great deal of distress is the result of a basic disconnect. Even as Americans hear frightening news about record numbers of infections and hospitalizations, there is growing confusion about testing, booster doses and medications — the very tools we use to protect ourselves from Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Tales From Crypto: A Billionaire Meme Feud Threatens Industry Unity
description: A dispute over “web3” in the cryptocurrency industry was publicly exposed in a Twitter spat between Jack Dorsey and Marc Andreessen. Here’s what it’s all about.
content: “You don’t own ‘web3.’ The VCs and their LPs do.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Can I Ask My Ex to Delete Those Nude Pics?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to make a delicate request without provocation, and more.
content: I recently broke up with someone I had been seeing for several months — not a long relationship, but a very intense one. In our breakup I realized that there was a lot about him I did not know, and I no longer trust him the way I once did. Is there an ethical way to ask him to delete nude pictures he may have on his phone? Part of me feels that if they are received, they are yours to keep, but I no longer feel comfortable with his holding them. Any suggestions on how to navigate this without retaliation? H.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Exxon Sets a 2050 Goal for Net-Zero Greenhouse Gas Emissions
description: The target does not account for the climate impact of its customers and suppliers, leaving the company lagging the commitments of some of its rivals.
content: HOUSTON — Exxon Mobil, under increasing pressure from investors to address climate change, announced on Tuesday that it had the “ambition” to reach zero net greenhouse gas emissions from its operations by 2050.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Wine Shop That’s Worth the Trip
description: Jonas Andersen, the former beverage director for Agern and the Great Northern Food Hall, hopped the Metro-North to open a store in Croton Falls, N.Y.
content: Jonas Andersen is tied to train stations. Coming from Grand Central Terminal, where he was the beverage director at Agern and the Great Northern Food Hall, he has just opened Folkways, a wine store in the former Croton Falls, N.Y., railway station. His new shop can take you to some uncommon destinations, with bottles from the Czech Republic and elsewhere in Eastern Europe, and lesser-known grapes like Italian canaiolo and French mauzac blanc. “There are great wines that are traditional in so many places, so why not highlight them?” he said. The shop also carries wine serving objects, books and magazines. Mr. Andersen and his partners — his wife, Natalie Marie Gehrels, and the sommelier Amanda Smeltz — spruced up the building, which had been a wine store for some 70 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Marchers Honor King and Call on Senate to Pass Voting Rights Legislation
description: The holiday came a day before the Senate returns to debate what is expected to be a doomed effort to pass the legislation. But advocates say they aren’t giving up.
content: WASHINGTON — Each year, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday is commemorated with marches, services and speeches. But the annual peace walk across the Frederick Douglass Memorial Bridge had an additional purpose on Monday: pushing the Senate to pass new voting rights legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Dentist Killed His Wife on an African Hunting Trip, U.S. Says
description: Lawrence Rudolph collected nearly $4.9 million in life insurance benefits after the fatal shooting of his wife, Bianca, in Zambia in 2016, according to court documents. He has pleaded not guilty.
content: Bianca Rudolph, an American big game hunter, traveled with her husband to Zambia, in southern Africa, in 2016, determined to add a leopard to her trophy collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: With Activision, Microsoft Bets on the Future
description: Video games have become weapons that tech titans wield to try to shape our future.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Biography About Argentina’s Most Famous Red Grape
description: “Malbec Mon Amour,” written by two directors at the Bodega Catena Zapata winery in Mendoza, tells the story of a grape that likes to travel.
content: Though its roots go deep in France and its origins might be traced to ancient Rome, the malbec grape has become identified with Argentina. It was brought there in the mid-19th century, where it became the country’s dominant red varietal. Dr. Laura Catena — a physician, the managing director of Bodega Catena Zapata, the founder of Catena Institute of Wine and a fourth generation member of the Catena Zapata family in Mendoza — has written a lively illustrated book, “Malbec Mon Amour,” with Alejandro Vigil, the wine director at the family’s winery. It offers general yet detailed information about winemaking and malbec history; describes grape cultivation, terroir and the effects of climate change; explains the specific characteristics of malbec and why it’s suited to conditions in Argentina, notably in the Cuyo region including Mendoza; and tells the story of the Catena Zapata family. For the professional, characteristics of the many Catena Zapata vineyards might be of interest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tommy Orange
title: A Recovery Journey That Isn’t
description: David Sanchez’ debut novel, “All Day Is a Long Time,” paints a kaleidoscopic portrait of life with addiction.
content: ALL DAY IS A LONG TIME
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Is Lodi Too Good for Rockefeller Center?
description: Many casual lunch spots specialize in convenient mediocrity. The new Italian cafe from Ignacio Mattos offers much more.
content: When somebody says a restaurant’s food is better than it has to be, it’s only half a compliment. Usually they mean that the food isn’t great, but it could be worse than it is and crowds would still keep coming because the place has other things going for it, like location or view.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Regulators aim to rewrite rules for big mergers.
description: U.S. antitrust leaders said they would focus on the tech industry’s free services as they strengthened the review process for corporate consolidation.
content: WASHINGTON — Top federal antitrust officials on Tuesday announced a review of how they approve mergers and acquisitions, in a broad effort to strengthen enforcement and clamp down on a surge of corporate consolidation, particularly in high tech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: How $1,000 a Month in Guaranteed Income Is Helping N.Y.C. Mothers
description: A new, privately funded program offers families in poverty a steady stream of cash.
content: The fliers that appeared at bus stops and nail salons and health clinics in Upper Manhattan last June sounded too good to be true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Milton Esterow
title: New Research Tracks Ancient Artifacts Looted by the Nazis
description: Scholars are increasingly focusing attention on the seizure and excavation of antiquities from Greece and other countries by German forces during World War II.
content: When the Nazis invaded Greece in 1941, Julius Ringel, a major general in the German army, took an active role in initiating illegal excavations on the island of Crete, where Minoan culture had flourished more than 3,000 years earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: European Parliament, Jostling for Relevance, Elects a New Leader
description: Roberta Metsola of Malta will succeed David Sassoli, an Italian politician who died last week, at a critical time for the institution.
content: BRUSSELS — The European Parliament elected a new president on Tuesday, with Roberta Metsola, a 43-year-old Maltese deputy, picked to lead the institution as its seeks to gain a more prominent place in the E.U. power structure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘Devil House,’ a Confident, Creepy Novel About a Wicked Unsolved Crime
description: John Darnielle’s new novel is about a true-crime writer who moves into a house where notorious murders had occurred decades earlier.
content: John Darnielle lobs his novels in from the margins of American life. They’re lonely books, and they always get to me.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Zeynep Tufekci
description: A conversation with the sociologist and New York Times Opinion columnist
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Zeynep Tufekci. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Luke Vander Ploeg, Kaitlin Roberts, Michael Simon Johnson, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano and Elisheba Ittoop
title: The Civilian Casualties of America’s Air Wars
description: Why is the death toll of U.S. strikes so staggeringly high?
content: Four years ago, Azmat Khan, an investigative reporter for The Times Magazine, told us the story of Basim Razzo, an Iraqi civilian whose home was targeted by a U.S.-led airstrike that killed his entire family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: In Arkansas, Trans Teens Await an Uncertain Future
description: Even as the medical community grapples with how best to provide care to transgender adolescents, some states seek to ban it outright.
content: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — For years, Zara Banks had been looking forward to her 14th birthday — the moment, last June, when her life would no longer be on pause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: France’s education minister draws ire for an Ibiza vacation as school Covid rules were changed.
description: The minister, Jean-Michel Blanquer, has led efforts to keep France’s schools open in the face of a sharp rise in cases caused by the Omicron variant.
content: A bitter dispute over Covid precautions in French schools turned into a political scandal on Tuesday as the local news media reported that the country’s education minister had been vacationing on the Mediterranean island of Ibiza while a contentious new testing protocol took shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave, Isabella Kwai and Eric Nagourney
title: An Island Nation Covered in Ash Now Worries About a Covid Intrusion
description: Aid workers risk bringing in a virus Tonga has so far kept out. But there are more immediate problems, as its government confirmed in its first statement since the disaster.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — A cleanup and evacuation operation has begun in Tonga, where the island nation’s government, after days of silence, said Tuesday night that an epic volcanic eruption and the tsunami and ash clouds that followed were an “unprecedented disaster.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Nines, an Elegant Supper Club, Opens in the Former Acme Space
description: Italian from the celebrity chef Fabio Viviani in Chelsea, counter-service tacos from Southern California, and more restaurant news.
content: Acme, the NoHo hot spot, is mostly history. Its underground bar and lounge remains in business, but the ground-floor restaurant has a new name and style. It is now something that has been on the restaurateur Jon Neidich’s wish list for years: a classy supper club, a throwback to high-end New York and lobby bars in grand hotels. (Mr. Neidich is running the project in the portfolio of his Golden Age Hospitality, which also includes Le Crocodile, Bar Blondeau and the Happiest Hour.) “Acme was closed for 14 months due to the pandemic, it had a good run and when we signed a new lease I decided to change it into something different,” he said. Sumptuously done in scarlet and swathed in corduroy, it has a small bar and lounge at the entrance. Then, behind a lush curtain is the main dining room with another bar, seating for 70 and a piano. The chef is Nicole Gajadhar from Saxon & Parole and the chef John Fraser’s restaurants. Her menu is luxurious, featuring oysters, caviar service, tuna tartare, foie gras, potato with caviar, gnudi with truffles, a club sandwich and a burger. The beverage director, Ashley Santoro from the Standard hotels, has assembled a list of classic cocktails, including a few nonalcoholic choices. The name is a reference to the address and the phrase describing fancy dress. (Opens Friday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lincoln Michel
title: In a Virus-Stricken Future, Humanity Endures Amid the Grief
description: Sequoia Nagamatsu’s debut novel, “How High We Go in the Dark,” is an expansive mosaic set in the wake of a devastating virus.
content: HOW HIGH WE GO IN THE DARKBy Sequoia Nagamatsu
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Neal E. Boudette
title: Can Anyone Satisfy Amazon’s Craving for Electric Vans?
description: The company has big plans to turn its delivery fleet green. But very few of the vehicles are made right now.
content: In the fall, Jeff Bezos tweeted praise for Rivian, a start-up under contract to make 100,000 electric delivery vans for Amazon, and its founder, R.J. Scaringe, calling him “one of the greatest entrepreneurs I’ve ever met.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Russia, Covid Tests, Naomi Osaka: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Mayor and the Challenge of Making the City Safer
description: Eric Adams made public safety a campaign issue. Now, as mayor, he will be held accountable.
content: Good morning. A death in a subway station over the weekend highlighted the challenges Mayor Eric Adams faces in making good on his promise to make the city safer. We’ll also look at new efforts to generate electricity from offshore wind projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: When Will the Omicron Surge Peak in California?
description: If the state follows the trajectory of other places hit hard by the variant, cases should begin leveling off soon.
content: Over the past week or so, new coronavirus infections have begun to fall in parts of the United States where the Omicron variant first proliferated: Chicago, Cleveland, New York, Washington, D.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino and Sharif Hassan
title: Two Earthquakes Strike Afghanistan, Killing at Least 27
description: The quakes struck about two hours apart in a western border province along the border with Turkmenistan.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two earthquakes struck a remote, mountainous area of western Afghanistan, killing at least 27 people and destroying hundreds of homes, officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: relinquish
description: This word has appeared in 122 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Will Biden Lose the Fight Over Voting Rights?
description: As Republican efforts to restrict voting access and reshape election administration have intensified, the Democrats' path to a solution has narrowed.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: A fourth shot may not offer much more protection against catching Omicron, an early Israeli study suggests.
description: The small study adds information to the debate over whether a fourth shot is advisable.
content: JERUSALEM — Preliminary results from a small Israeli study examining the effects of a fourth coronavirus vaccine dose suggest that despite an increase in antibody levels, the additional dose a few months after a third shot may not do much more to prevent infection with the Omicron variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Shesol
title: Did John F. Kennedy and the Democrats Steal the 1960 Election?
description: “Campaign of the Century,” a new book by Irwin F. Gellman, revives an old contention that Richard Nixon actually won the presidency in 1960.
content: CAMPAIGN OF THE CENTURYKennedy, Nixon, and the Election of 1960By Irwin F. Gellman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Profit fell 13 percent for Goldman Sachs in 4th quarter as it raised employee pay.
description: For the year, Goldman notched its largest profit ever, $21.6 billion, helped by deal-making by its investment bankers.
content: Goldman Sachs on Tuesday reported a record $21.6 billion profit last year, but its fourth-quarter earnings fell as it bumped up pay, repeating a pattern experienced by some of the country’s other big banks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chua
title: How the English Language Conquered the World
description: Rosemary Salomone’s “The Rise of English” looks at the economic, social and cultural impact of English around the world.
content: THE RISE OF ENGLISHGlobal Politics and the Power of LanguageBy Rosemary Salomone
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘The Kite Runner’ Is Coming to Broadway
description: The 2007 play based on Khaled Hosseini’s novel has been widely produced, including on the West End in London. It will come to Broadway in July.
content: A stage adaptation of the best-selling novel “The Kite Runner” will be presented on Broadway in July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: 2 Earthquakes in Remote Area of Western Afghanistan Kill at Least 22
description: There were fears the death toll could rise as the first rescuers reached some of the mountainous villages struck by the temblors in one of Afghanistan’s most impoverished regions.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two earthquakes rattled Afghanistan’s western Badghis Province along the border with Turkmenistan on Monday, killing at least 22 people, a local official said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Be Grateful We Have Different Last Names’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: When I was a newlywed nearly 30 years ago, my mother-in-law would introduce me as “Debby, Dave’s wife; she didn’t take his name.” It was true, but it rankled me because she was otherwise very gracious and accepting. So I made light of it. “You should be grateful we have different last names,” I’d say whenever I published revealing humor essays about my life with her son. Pat has dementia now. She calls me her daughter, sister or friend. None are true. All are loving. Proof yet again that labels and names mean little in love. — Debby Waldman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Once a Hostage, She’s Now Running for President of Colombia
description: Ingrid Betancourt’s candidacy comes at a critical time, when Colombians are fed up with the political establishment and the future of the peace agreement is at stake.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Ingrid Betancourt, a former congresswoman and one-time guerrilla hostage who has come to symbolize both the brutality of Colombia’s long war and the country’s efforts at reconciliation, will run for president, she said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Ashley Wong
title: Bill de Blasio Says He Won’t Run for Governor After All
description: Mr. de Blasio, the former New York City mayor, had signaled for months that he planned to run for governor, but he faced long odds in a crowded Democratic primary.
content: Bill de Blasio, the former mayor of New York City, said on Tuesday that he would not run for governor of New York, as he had been widely expected to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: In Quest for Energy Independence, Mexico Is Buying a Texas Oil Refinery
description: President López Obrador wants to halt most oil exports and imports of gasoline and other fuels. Critics say he is reneging on Mexico’s climate change commitments.
content: DEER PARK, Texas — Two giant murals, on storage tanks at an oil refinery here, depict the rebels led by Sam Houston who secured Texas’ independence from Mexico in the 1830s. This week those murals will become the property of the Mexican national oil company, which is acquiring full control of the refinery.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What’s Left for the Weeknd to Conquer?
description: “Dawn FM” suggests at least one future direction for the pop powerhouse, who’s spent a decade making careful moves.
content: Following the Weeknd’s 2020 album, “After Hours,” which included the global hit “Blinding Lights,” it may have seemed as if he had nowhere else to go — that he’d finally reached the summit of the mountain he’d spent the decade climbing, starting out as a freaky recalibrator of R&B and ending up making unifying 1980s-style hits that need no translation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
title: Jan. 6 Panel Subpoenas Giuliani, Digging Into False Vote Fraud Claims
description: The House committee investigating the Capitol riot called for documents and testimony from Rudolph W. Giuliani and other members of President Donald J. Trump’s legal team.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol on Tuesday subpoenaed Rudolph W. Giuliani and other members of the legal team that pursued a set of conspiracy-filled lawsuits on behalf of former President Donald J. Trump in which they made unsubstantiated claims of fraud in the 2020 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Recaps Trump’s Latest Rally
description: “Thousands of people showed up, because there’s nothing to do in Florence, Arizona,” Kimmel said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Gunna Beats the Weeknd in a Close Race for No. 1
description: In a tale of two surprise albums with striking cover art, “deluxe” versions and retail discounts, the Atlanta rapper’s “DS4Ever” won by a nose.
content: Last week, two new albums vied for No. 1 on the Billboard 200 chart, with similar marketing arsenals and big fan bases set to click away on streaming services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: Kyle MacLachlan Opened the Prada Show, but Don’t Get Too Excited
description: The actor approached his spot on Prada’s fall 2022 runway as if it was a wonderful role — albeit one he may not reprise.
content: When the actor Kyle MacLachlan opened the Prada men’s wear show in Milan on Sunday, many were surprised and delighted to see Special Agent Dale Cooper strut the runway. But others wondered if Mr. MacLachlan was in fact making a return to fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Eileen Sullivan
title: Texas Hostage Taker Was Known to British Intelligence
description: Malik Faisal Akram was listed as a “subject of interest” in 2020 by Britain’s MI5 security service, according to British and U.S. officials. But he had since been deemed to no longer be a risk.
content: LONDON — The British man who took four people hostage at a Texas synagogue over the weekend before being killed was known to British intelligence services, British and U.S. officials said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Wharton and Koren Shadmi
title: The Coffee Maker
description: James Hoffmann is one of the most followed men in caffeine. Here’s an illustrated look at how he became an expert.
content: Follow NYT Food on Twitter and NYT Cooking on Instagram, Facebook, YouTube and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Faith Ringgold Mural at Rikers Island to Move to Brooklyn Museum
description: The artist requested that her painting, dedicated to incarcerated women in the jail complex, head to the museum because of safety concerns. City officials agreed.
content: In 2019, the painter Faith Ringgold traveled to Rikers Island so that she could see how her first public art commission, a 1972 mural called “For the Women’s House,” was faring. Not so good, she decided, and the artist, who is 91, continued to quietly wage her campaign to see her work, which hung in a forlorn hallway behind plexiglass where few could see it, relocated to the Brooklyn Museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Anton Troianovski
title: Blinken Will Meet With Russia as U.S. Pushes for More Diplomacy
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will meet with Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia in Geneva on Friday as the United States warns that Russia could soon attack Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — Seeking to head off a potential assault on Ukraine, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will meet with Russia’s foreign minister on Friday as the two sides explore whether there is still a diplomatic path to avoiding a conflict in Eastern Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex McElroy
title: Why Holding a Grudge Is So Satisfying
description: A good grudge is watered down, drinkable and refreshingly effervescent, the low-calorie lager to resentment’s bootleg grain alcohol.
content: During a fourth-grade sleepover, I awoke in the night frothed over by Barbasol. The other kids were tucked in their sleeping bags, snoring. I woke them to see if they, too, had been creamed; they hadn’t been but seemed surprised and angry on my behalf and offered to help find the culprit. I wanted to go back to sleep, but they insisted we keep searching. And then they could no longer maintain the charade — who else could it have been? — and their laughter emerged, thunderous and harsh. I returned to my sleeping bag, pretending I wasn’t embarrassed. By morning, I was praising the ingenuity of their prank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Grace Ashford
title: Surprise in $216 Billion Budget Plan: New York Is Awash in Money
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul unveiled a record-setting new budget plan, as state officials project balanced budgets through 2027, with none of the typical warnings of billion-dollar shortfalls.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Just a year ago, New York State officials warned that the coronavirus had decimated state coffers, potentially requiring significant spending cuts. But on Tuesday, riding a windfall of federal aid and a boost in tax dollars, Gov. Kathy Hochul released a $216.3 billion budget proposal that she described as a “once-in-a-generation opportunity” to spur the state’s recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Naomi Osaka Returns, Ready or Not
description: After a tumultuous year and a four-month layoff during which she questioned what she wanted from tennis, Osaka is back on the court. “I’m not sure if this is going to work out well.”
content: On Dec. 31, as the final hours of 2021 ticked away, Naomi Osaka wrote on Twitter: “I’ve never been more excited for a year to be over.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Stafford and Beckham Get Playoff Vindication in Rams’ Win
description: Matthew Stafford and Odell Beckham Jr., productive stars with little postseason success, propelled the Rams to a wild-card round victory over the Cardinals on Monday.
content: INGLEWOOD, Calif. — Thirty minutes before the biggest game of Matthew Stafford’s N.F.L. career, he tossed passes in warm-ups with his coach, Sean McVay, standing close by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: Time Is Ben Roethlisberger’s Harshest Critic
description: In his 18 seasons as Steelers quarterback, Ben Roethlisberger’s success eclipsed the sexual assault allegations he faced. They tarnish consideration of his legacy.
content: Ben Roethlisberger led one final drive for the Pittsburgh Steelers on Sunday night in a game that was over before it had officially ended, the same as his N.F.L. career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘At-Home Coronavirus Tests Are Inaccessible to Blind People’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about how at-home coronavirus tests, with visual cues and complex steps, are often inaccessible to blind people and how workarounds might make these tests more accessible.
content: Featured Article: “At-Home Coronavirus Tests Are Inaccessible to Blind People” by Amanda Morris
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Skolnick
title: Why Do They Swim-Bike-Run So Fast? Data.
description: The most advanced science in the triathlon world can be found in Norway, where athletes embrace the data found in heat sensors, oxygen measuring masks and their feces.
content: In November, under stormy, tropical skies, the reigning Olympic men’s triathlon champion, Kristian Blummenfelt leapt from a pier into the Caribbean Sea. Then, 7 hours 21 minutes 12 seconds later, after swimming 2.4 miles, cycling more than 112 and running 26.2, he snapped the tape to win the Cozumel Ironman in Mexico and become the fastest ever at the Ironman distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen and Gabriella Angotti-Jones
title: Sports Betting’s Next Big Election Battles Are in California
description: Tribal casinos, online sports books, card rooms and others may spend $200 million this year on competing visions for the biggest untapped sports betting market left in the United States.
content: TEMECULA, Calif. — Legal sports betting in the United States accelerated in 2021 as a flurry of states either overcame legislative logjams, as Ohio did just before Christmas, or signed off on online wagering, as New York did just after Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman and Kevin Draper
title: A Nike Executive Seeks a Family’s Forgiveness for a 1965 Murder
description: Barbara Mack hugged Larry Miller after he apologized for killing her brother, Edward David White. But if she were 30 years younger, she told him, “I would have been across that table at you.”
content: PHILADELPHIA — Barbara Mack lives a block from the corner where her teenage brother was shot to death while on his way home from work on Sept. 30, 1965. Hasan Adams was only 8 months old when the bullet took his father. Azizah Arline was months from being born and never met her dad. More than half a century later, they have finally received an apology from, and discussed restitution with, the man who committed the murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why a Blue City Is Feeling the Blues
description: New York is paying a price for Wall Street’s economic dominance.
content: Remember when New York City was doomed? The first wave of the Covid-19 pandemic hit the city like a hammer, killing more than 20,000 New Yorkers over the course of a few months. And many commentators asserted that it was New York’s lifestyle — in particular, its uniquely high population density and reliance on mass transit — that made it so vulnerable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Emma Raducanu Rediscovers Winning Ways Against Sloane Stephens
description: Despite being a Grand Slam champion herself, Raducanu had never faced one until she played and defeated Stephens in the first round of the Australian Open.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Emma Raducanu wasted no time in announcing her presence in her first Grand Slam match since her stunning run to last year’s U.S. Open title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Top Editor Files Discrimination Suit Against The New York Post
description: In the lawsuit, Michelle Gotthelf said the tabloid’s longtime top editor, Col Allan, had retaliated against her after she turned down a sexual proposition.
content: A former high-level editor at The New York Post claimed in a discrimination lawsuit filed on Tuesday that she had endured “several years of sex-based harassment” during her more than two decades at the tabloid, saying its longtime editor in chief retaliated against her after she reported to company officers that he had sexually harassed her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Listen to Keyboard Music by Bach (No, Not That One)
description: The extraordinary range of C.P.E. Bach, a son of J.S., is on display in a new album from the pianist Marc-André Hamelin.
content: The subject of the pianist Marc-André Hamelin’s latest album is Bach — no, not that one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Brad Leone Takes On the Pork Roll
description: The Bon Appétit video personality has teamed up with Olympia Provisions on his own version of a New Jersey favorite.
content: Pork roll or Taylor ham, depending on where you live, is a cured meat product that’s similar to bologna but with more character, flavor and texture. Now Olympia Provisions, a meat company in Portland, Ore., has collaborated with Brad Leone, a chef and video star at Bon Appétit, to make its own mildly smoky version using local pasture-raised pork. It’s the first product that’s also labeled Leone & Sons, a company being developed by Mr. Leone. Sizzled on a griddle or a grill, this pork roll does the trick in a breakfast sandwich. Cube and skewer it with olives for cocktail snacks or sear pieces with cheese for sliders and cue the playoffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
title: Boris Johnson signals that he might ease England’s virus rules.
description: The prime minister is under intense political pressure over claims that he lied to Parliament about parties held in Downing Street during a lockdown.
content: LONDON — With Omicron cases beginning to fall, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain on Tuesday signaled possible plans to ease coronavirus restrictions in England, a move likely to mollify critics in his restive Conservative Party at a time when he is besieged by career-threatening political scandals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: This Way to the Pandemic Exit
description: As Milan men’s wear tentatively returns to live showings, labels like Zegna, Brunello Cucinelli and Dsquared try dreaming their way out of grim reality.
content: MILAN — Sometimes it’s the random adjacencies that make you savor life. You can’t exactly call it coincidence — or even entirely unexpected — that one moment during fashion week you find yourself sitting at Zegna corporate headquarters viewing a men’s wear show from a venerable house that went public, and abruptly ditched its trademark suiting for a monkishly modular wardrobe, and the next (well, two hours afterward) are being barraged by a welter of images at a Dsquared show epitomizing the kitchen-sink school of fashion styling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Manley
title: What Fictional House Would You Want to Stay In?
description: Fans of “Home Alone” had the chance to spend a night at the McCallister family home in December. What pop culture-inspired sleepover interests you?
content: Have you ever dreamed of spending the night in the Weasleys’ home from “Harry Potter,” Betty’s house from “Riverdale” or SpongeBob’s pineapple under the sea? If you could spend the night in any home from your favorite movie, show or book, where would you stay?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This SoHo Brewery Tour Includes the Neighborhood
description: Torch and Crown is including a walking tour of the area in its brewery tours.
content: The Manhattan brewery Torch & Crown has introduced walking tours. Erin Fitzpatrick, the guide, begins at the brewery in SoHo and leads participants through the neighborhood and parts of Lower Manhattan, describing the architecture, the history of beer in New York and some classic local bars before returning to tour the brewery and have lunch (beers included).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Greenblatt
title: Before He Died, the Writer Roberto Calasso Had the Old Testament on His Mind
description: In “The Book of All Books,” the great Italian polymath offers his interpretation of biblical stories.
content: THE BOOK OF ALL BOOKSBy Roberto CalassoTranslated by Tim Parks
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: It’s the Word
description: Kate Schutzengel makes her New York Times debut.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Kate Schutzengel on her New York Times Crossword debut. This is our fifth debut of the year, and boy is it a silly one (in the best possible way)! Before we get to the theme, though, I want to discuss one clue convention that can be particularly confusing to new solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Coconut Cake Grants Wishes
description: Harold Moore, the chief culinary officer for the Charlie Palmer Collective, is selling his signature dessert to raise money for the Make-A-Wish Foundation.
content: The chef Harold Moore’s signature dessert is his lush coconut cake: four layers, with creamy frosting and a coating of lightly toasted coconut. The spotlight started to shine on it when he was at Commerce in the West Village, which closed in 2015. Now the chief culinary officer for the Charlie Palmer Collective’s restaurants, he is also baking the coconut cake for charity with Mr. Palmer’s blessing. The price of the cake is donated to the Make-A-Wish Foundation Metro New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Sharon Otterman
title: New York City’s mayor says ‘we are winning’ against Omicron, as experts urge caution.
description: The number of known cases is still much higher than last winter, and during the devastating first wave in the spring of 2020, testing was scarce, leaving many cases unreported.
content: Mayor Eric Adams said on Tuesday that New York City was winning its war against the Omicron surge, noting that the numbers of coronavirus cases and hospitalizations, while still extremely high, have started to drop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geraldo L. Cadava
title: Latino Voters Are Key to 2024, and They’re Not Always Buying What Democrats Are Selling
description: Given the political stakes as well as the stakes for Latino families, Democratic leaders must do better.
content: The shift toward Donald Trump by Latino voters was one of the more surprising takeaways of the 2020 presidential election. The findings of recent polls and reports — that Latinos may still be sliding toward Republicans — are even more disconcerting for Democrats. Given the political stakes as well as the stakes for Latino families, Democratic leaders must do better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: American L.G.B.T.Q.+ Museum Names First Executive Director
description: Ben Garcia will lead the first museum dedicated to L.G.B.T.Q. history and culture in the city, which seeks to strike a careful balance between New York and national queer history.
content: Almost five years exactly after its conception, the American L.G.B.T.Q.+ Museum — which aims to open its doors in 2024 — has found its first executive director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: Swipe Right When You See a Conference Room You Like
description: Mobile apps for office buildings have become popular as employers try to entice staff back on site by making work-related tasks convenient and safe.
content: Employees returning to the office in the midst of the pandemic are bound to arrive with a new set of questions: What health precautions have been put in place? How crowded is the cafeteria? Which meeting rooms are available? How do visitors gain entry to the building?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Omicron prompts more cruise lines to cancel trips.
description: In recent weeks, hundreds of passengers have contracted the coronavirus aboard ships.
content: Royal Caribbean International and Celebrity Cruises have canceled several trips as the Omicron variant continues to wreak havoc with the cruise industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Why Christine Ebersole’s Home Is Furnished With Broadway Castoffs
description: Thanks to an impressive career, the Tony Award winner has acquired conversation pieces from a number of notable Broadway shows.
content: Christine Ebersole’s journey from an impeccably renovated midcentury house in the San Fernando Valley to a tatterdemalion side-hall colonial in Maplewood, N.J., involved one husband, three children and seven pets. But it began with an agent who suddenly stopped dialing for dollars on his client’s behalf in the late 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Are Progressives Hating on Antitrust?
description: A Biden initiative comes in for weirdly vehement criticism.
content: Inflation has become a big issue for the U.S. economy and, of course, a big political headache for the Biden administration. But while many people have been urging President Biden to “focus” on inflation, there have been many fewer suggestions about what he might actually do. (Wander around the White House muttering, “I’m focused, I’m focused”?) For the most part, controlling inflation is now a matter for monetary policy, and the main thing Biden can do is let the technocrats who control money do their job — which means not engaging in Trump-style haranguing of the Federal Reserve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise, Andrew Ross Sorkin, Kellen Browning and Michael J. de la Merced
title: Microsoft will buy Activision Blizzard, betting $70 billion on the future of games.
description: With the deal, the largest in the software maker’s history, Microsoft will acquire Activision’s huge pool of users and access to some of the world’s most popular games.
content: SEATTLE — Microsoft plans to buy the powerhouse but troubled video game company Activision Blizzard for nearly $70 billion, its biggest deal ever and one that places a major bet that people will be spending more and more time in the digital world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: You Can Still Own a Caravaggio, but It Comes With a House (and a Hefty Price)
description: A much anticipated auction for a $500 million villa in Rome that boasts a Caravaggio ceiling fresco failed to get any offers.
content: ROME — It was heralded as the real estate deal of the century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lacy Crawford
title: A Black Graduate of an Elite Boarding School Gets Real
description: Kendra James was a legacy student at Taft, but wasn’t made to feel like a member of a proud tradition while she was there.
content: ADMISSIONSA Memoir of Surviving Boarding SchoolBy Kendra James
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: More delays, more uncertainty, more masks: Manhattan employers adjust plans once again.
description: A new survey of 187 businesses shows just how much the Omicron variant has upended plans to get back into the office.
content: Almost a quarter of Manhattan’s major employers don’t know when their offices will start getting back to normal as the Omicron variant of the coronavirus roils employers’ back-to-work plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Bradley
title: The Artists and Designers Making Tarot Decks for Today
description: For centuries, the playing cards have captivated seekers of all kinds — including creative types — and have become especially popular of late.
content: Dior’s spring 2021 haute couture collection debuted last January with a lush short film created by Matteo Garrone that opens with a tarot reading that transports its querent to a mysterious chateau populated by sumptuously dressed figures from the card deck — the Fool, the Empress, an anthropomorphized Sun and Moon — who act as signposts as she travels down one corridor and then another. The short, and the looks it showcased, which were designed by the brand’s artistic director, Maria Grazia Chiuri, was partly inspired by Italo Calvino’s 1973 novel, “The Castle of Crossed Destinies,” in which the characters lose the power of speech and can communicate only through tarot cards, and it nodded to Christian Dior’s well-documented interest in the divinatory arts, on which he particularly relied during the precarious days of the Second World War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Omicron’s effect on the pandemic.
content: Speaking at the online World Economic Forum, Dr. Anthony Fauci, President Biden’s top medical adviser for Covid, said it was too soon to say how the Omicron variant would change the course of the pandemic. The sheer volume of cases could have a meaningful effect on collective immunity, he said, but the evolution of the pandemic was still unclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Larry Fink Defends Stakeholder Capitalism
description: Companies thinking beyond profits isn’t “woke,” the BlackRock founder argued in his latest letter to Wall Street chiefs.
content: As the founder and C.E.O. of BlackRock, Larry Fink commands the attention of business leaders, thanks to the $10 trillion that his investment firm manages. After years of pushing corporate America to look beyond profits and embrace a broader social purpose — which has attracted criticism from all corners — he is using his latest annual letter to C.E.O.s to clarify, and defend, his approach.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 18, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 18, 2022.
content: An article on Sunday about the eruption of an underwater volcano near the South Pacific island of Tonga referred incorrectly to New Zealand’s location relative to Tonga. It is southwest, not northeast, of Tonga.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Said to Have Asked About Trump’s Role in Jan. 6 Riot
description: A court filing by a defendant in a Capitol riot case said the Justice Department was looking for information about a possible “organized conspiracy” involving the former president.
content: For months, the Justice Department has provided little public indication of whether, or how seriously, it is investigating the role played by former President Donald J. Trump in the violent attack on the Capitol last Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: At Prada, It’s in With the Old
description: Opening their fall show with Kyle MacLachlan and closing it with Jeff Goldblum, Miuccia Prada and Raf Simons make a case for dressing up like grown-ups.
content: MILAN — Just about the last “ism” no one gets noisy about is the one regarding age. Fashion, in particular, has been a chronic offender, fetishizing millennials and tapping a foot while waiting for the olds to pack up and check into a home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gerald Narciso
title: In Times Like These, Even a Beached Barge Can Spark Joy
description: Washed ashore during a fierce November storm, a massive barge has become both a popular sightseeing spot and meme in Vancouver.
content: On Christmas morning, Patrick Levesque woke up to the perfect elements for his big day. A thick coat of snow had accumulated overnight in Vancouver, providing a magical backdrop for the wedding proposal that he had been plotting for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Hochul Outpaces Foes by Raising Record-High $21.6 Million for Campaign
description: The fund-raising haul cements Gov. Kathy Hochul as the prohibitive favorite to win a full term as governor of New York in November.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York has raised $21.6 million for her election campaign in the five months since she ascended to the state’s highest office, a record-smashing sum that positions her as the prohibitive favorite in the race for governor, if not the dominant figure in New York State politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Scholars Doubt New Theory on Anne Frank’s Betrayal
description: A new book that names a Jewish notary as a suspect made headlines. Now that World War II and Holocaust experts have had time to review its claims, many doubt the methods and conclusion.
content: AMSTERDAM — “Who betrayed Anne Frank?” is a common question visitors ask at the Anne Frank House, a museum built around the secret annex where the teenage diarist hid from the Nazis for more than two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Zeynep Tufekci on How to Prepare for the Pandemic’s Next Phase
description: Zeynep Tufekci helps me understand the systems-wide failure on Covid — and how we can prepare for the pandemic’s next phase.
content: I remember thinking, as Covid ravaged the country in December 2020, that at least the holidays the next year would be better. There would be more vaccines, more treatments, more immunity. Instead, we got Omicron and a confusing new phase of the pandemic. What do you do with a variant that is both monstrously more infectious and somewhat milder? What do you say about another year when we didn’t have enough tests, enough ventilation or the best guidance on masks? And how do you handle the fracturing politics of a changing pandemic in an exhausted country?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Detainees Sue Arkansas Jail That Gave Them Ivermectin to Treat Covid
description: For months, the jail’s doctor has promoted the drug, which health experts say should not be used to treat or prevent Covid-19.
content: Detainees at an Arkansas jail who had Covid-19 were unknowingly treated by the detention center’s doctor with ivermectin, a drug that health officials have continually said is dangerous and should not be used to treat or prevent a coronavirus infection, according to a federal lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union on behalf of four detainees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Two top aides to Pope Francis test positive for coronavirus.
description: The infected men meet frequently with Francis, who is 85, but it was not clear when they last saw the pope.
content: ROME — The Vatican said Tuesday that two of Pope Francis’ top aides — Cardinal Pietro Parolin, the Vatican’s secretary of state, and his deputy, Archbishop Edgar Peña Parra — had tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Survive an Avalanche
description: Move to the top of the debris. Create an air pocket in front of your face.
content: “The snow breaks all around you like a pane of glass,” says Karl Birkeland, director of the U.S. Forest Service’s National Avalanche Center in Bozeman, Mont. And when it does, listen for what Birkeland calls “a whumpf sound,” as the slab of snow fractures. Don’t wait to see what happens. Try to find solid ground by moving to the edge of the flow or digging into the stable base layer using your hands, ski edges or poles. If you are swept away, do everything possible to maneuver yourself toward the top of the debris. “If you get buried, you want to be shallow so your friends can dig you out,” Birkeland says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Congress Can Trade Stocks or Keep the Public Trust. Not Both.
description: Why on earth are representatives and senators allowed to trade stocks?
content: Most Americans believe that most politicians are corrupt. How depressing — not to mention how terrible for the health of democracy. After all, if the system is broken and everyone is a crook anyway, why not elect a reality TV grifter with a smashed ethical compass to be president?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells and Tejal Rao
title: Two Restaurant Critics, Two Perspectives on Indoor Dining
description: Our New York and Los Angeles critics discuss Covid precautions, testing and dining-room anxiety.
content: As the Omicron variant surges across the United States, Covid cases are at an all-time high. But unlike in the spring of 2020, restaurants largely remain open (with a growing number of exceptions). Our restaurant critics, Pete Wells and Tejal Rao, are based in New York and Los Angeles, respectively. In both cities, restaurant workers are required to be fully vaccinated, as are diners eating indoors. The two critics conversed about their comfort levels with dining indoors, and the differences — or similarities — they are seeing in their cities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Worries in China That Population May Soon Shrink
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 18, 2022.
content: “The year 2021 will go down in Chinese history as the year that China last saw population growth in its long history.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Your Word of the Year
description: If you had to choose just one to represent your hopes for 2022, what would it be?
content: The Well section recently challenged readers to come up with a single word to set the tone of their life for the next 12 months. Before you read what others chose, pick your own, and tell us why you chose it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Nocturna’ Review: A Dark Night of the Soul
description: A seemingly haunted apartment building terrorizes a bewildered old man in this psychological thriller.
content: Divided into two distinct features — the first of which can stand alone, while the second may work best as a dialogue with the first — “Nocturna” weaves memory and nightmare into a haunting tale of loneliness and regret.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: The Dumbledore of Clowning
description: The French master teacher Philippe Gaulier has worked with stars like Sacha Baron Cohen. But at 78, are his methods, which include insults, outdated?
content: ÉTAMPES, France — It’s unlikely anyone alive has made more clowns cry than Philippe Gaulier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Daniel Radcliffe to Play Weird Al Yankovic in New Biopic
description: The film, “Weird: The Al Yankovic Story,” will begin production next month and will be available for streaming on the Roku Channel.
content: For years, actors have challenged themselves by disappearing into portrayals of famous musicians. Think Joaquin Phoenix as Johnny Cash. Don Cheadle as Miles Davis. Jennifer Lopez as Selena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and David E. Sanger
title: Russia Thins Out Its Embassy in Ukraine, a Possible Clue to Putin’s Next Move
description: The slow evacuation may be part propaganda, part preparation for a conflict or part feint, Ukrainian and U.S. officials say. It could be all three.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — The week before intensive diplomatic meetings began over the buildup of Russian troops on the Ukrainian border, American and Ukrainian officials watched from afar as Russia began emptying out its embassy in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Has the Pandemic Changed Your Relationship?
description: Tell us about it.
content: For good and bad, the pandemic has had a huge impact on our romantic relationships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Romer
title: How A.I. Conquered Poker
description: Good poker players have always known that they need to maintain a balance between bluffing and playing it straight. Now they can do so perfectly.
content: Last November in the cavernous Amazon Room of Las Vegas’s Rio casino, two dozen men dressed mostly in sweatshirts and baseball caps sat around three well-worn poker tables playing Texas Hold ’em. Occasionally a few passers-by stopped to watch the action, but otherwise the players pushed their chips back and forth in dingy obscurity. Except for the taut, electric stillness with which they held themselves during a hand, there was no outward sign that these were the greatest poker players in the world, nor that they were, as the poker saying goes, “playing for houses,” or at least hefty down payments. This was the first day of a three-day tournament whose official name was the World Series of Poker Super High Roller, though the participants simply called it “the 250K,” after the $250,000 each had put up to enter it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: What’s All the Hype About the Metaverse?
description: Microsoft cited the metaverse as a reason for buying Activision Blizzard for $68.7 billion. Let’s break down what that really means.
content: The term “metaverse” is everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Ali Mitgutsch, Inventive Children’s Book Illustrator, Dies at 86
description: The father of a German genre called Wimmelbuch, he delighted readers with detailed, cartoonish tableaus crammed with jokes and anecdotes.
content: BERLIN — Hippies dance to the Beatles while the downstairs neighbor uses her broom trying to get them to turn down the music. Several apartments up, a boy with a bad toothache is waiting for the dentist. The mailman is forced to climb the stairs because the kids have taken over the elevator. In the flat below that of a man with a broken leg, a married couple has just moved in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below, along with some solving tips and tricks by Wordplay’s own Deb Amlen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah E. Lipstadt
title: For Jews, Going to Services Is an Act of Courage
description: Going to services should not be an act of courage.
content: Baruch atah Adonai, eloheinu melech ha-olam, matir asurim. Blessed are you, God, sovereign of the universe, who frees the captives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Jeremy Engle and John Otis
title: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Supreme Court Ruling, Volcanic Eruption, No. 1 Album
description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

title: Is Pluto a Planet? What’s a Planet, Anyway?
description: More than 15 years after Pluto was demoted to dwarf planet, the debate, even among scientists, continues.
content: More than 15 years after Pluto was demoted to dwarf planet, the debate, even among scientists, continues.

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Sudanese Security Forces Kill 7 People as Thousands Protest
description: Security forces fatally shot seven people and injured at least 100 others, a doctors group said, during the latest mass protests against an Oct. 25 military coup that derailed Sudan’s transition to democracy.
content: Security forces fatally shot seven people and injured at least 100 others, a doctors group said, during the latest mass protests against an Oct. 25 military coup that derailed Sudan’s transition to democracy.

description: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City expressed optimism in the fight against the Omicron surge, citing drops in the average number of cases recorded daily and hospitalizations.
